hero_subtitle: Comprehensive legal solutions and personalized guidance for all your immigration needs.
about_description: Our team brings decades of combined experience from immigration offices, providing specialized representation for all immigration matters in Jacksonville, Florida. We are committed to guiding the Hispanic community through the complexities of U.S. immigration law.
description_visa: Strategic guidance for obtaining work authorization and employment-based visas in the United States.
description_Residency: Complete representation for family-based and employment-based green card applications.
description_Citizenship: End-to-end assistance with U.S. citizenship applications and naturalization proceedings.
description_Immigration: Aggressive representation in deportation proceedings and immigration court.
services_description: Full-spectrum immigration solutions with expert legal counsel for individuals and families.
description1: Thorough evaluation of your circumstances to determine optimal immigration pathways.
description2: Meticulous compilation and preparation of all required supporting evidence.
description3: Precise submission of applications to USCIS with premium case management.
description4: Dedicated representation through final adjudication and beyond.

intro.title: Your Trusted Immigration Partner
intro.description: Our expert advisors provide personalized assistance for all your immigration needs, ensuring a smooth and successful journey to residency. We work directly with USCIS services, ensuring accuracy and efficiency in every application.

serviceItems.title: Citizenship
serviceItems.description: Assistance with Form N-400 for a smooth citizenship process.
serviceItems.content: USCIS Form N-400: Application for U.S. Citizenship
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: To qualify for U.S. citizenship, you must have been a permanent resident (Green Card holder) for at least 5 years. If you are married to a U.S. citizen, this period is reduced to 3 years. During this time, you must have lived continuously in the United States.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText: You must have been physically present in the United States for at least 30 months out of the last 5 years before filing your application. If you are married to a U.S. citizen, you must have been present for at least 18 months out of the last 3 years.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText: To be eligible, you must demonstrate good moral character. This includes paying taxes, obeying U.S. laws, and having no serious criminal record. USCIS will evaluate your conduct during the required residency period.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText: One of the final steps to obtaining citizenship is taking the Oath of Allegiance to the United States. By doing so, you pledge to support and defend the Constitution and the laws of the country, renouncing allegiance to other countries.
serviceItems.contentFinal: If you meet these basic requirements, you can proceed to complete and submit Form N-400 to begin your path to U.S. citizenship. Good luck!

serviceItems.title: Employment Authorization
serviceItems.description: Expert guidance on Form I-765 to obtain your Employment Authorization Document.
serviceItems.content: Everything You Need to Know About EAD
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Employment Authorization Document that allows legal work in the United States
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: The Employment Authorization Document (EAD) is a work permit issued by USCIS that demonstrates your legal right to work in the U.S. It is obtained through Form I-765 and contains: your name, photo, A-number, immigration category, and validity dates.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
People who are not citizens or permanent residents but need to work legally, including:
- Asylum seekers/refugees
- Students (certain types of employment)
- Adjustment of status applicants
- TPS beneficiaries
- Spouses of visa holders (K, J-2, E, L)
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Initial EAD: First application
2. Renewal: Submit ‚â§120 days before expiration
3. Replacement: For lost/damaged cards

Process: Submit Form I-765 to receive temporary authorization (duration varies by immigration status). Approval allows work for any employer without sponsorship.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
- Legal work authorization
- No employer restrictions
- Valid for completing Form I-9
- Work flexibility

Note: Processing times vary. Renew early to avoid employment interruptions.
serviceItems.contentFinal: For updated information on requirements and processing times, always check the official USCIS website.

serviceItems.title: Green Card
serviceItems.description: Support with Form I-485 to adjust your status to permanent resident.
serviceItems.content: Adjustment of Status for Permanent Residence
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Green Card application from within the United States
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-485 allows certain foreigners in the U.S. to change their immigration status to permanent resident (obtain Green Card). It must be filed with USCIS and is available for people with:
- Approved immigrant petition
- Current priority date
- Valid status in the country
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
1. Be physically present in the U.S.
2. Have an approved immigrant petition (unless asylum/refugee)
3. Visa available (current priority date)
4. No serious immigration violations
5. Be admissible to the U.S.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Family: Spouses, parents or children of U.S. citizens
2. Employment: Employer-sponsored
3. Asylum/Refugees: After 1 year in status
4. Special Cases: VAWA, SIV, among others

*People outside the U.S. must follow consular processing
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Advantages:
- Allows work with EAD while processing
- Possibility to travel with Advance Parole
- Path to citizenship (after 3-5 years)

Process:
1. Submit I-485 + documents
2. Attend biometrics
3. Interview (in most cases)
4. USCIS decision

*Refugees are fee-exempt
serviceItems.contentFinal: For more information about specific requirements and necessary documentation, visit the official USCIS website or consult with a qualified immigration attorney.

serviceItems.title: Visas
serviceItems.description: Help with Form DS-160 for B1/B2 visitor visas for business or tourism.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Online application for business (B1) or tourism (B2) visas
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
The DS-160 is the mandatory electronic form to apply for:

‚Ä¢ Business visas (B1)
‚Ä¢ Tourism visas (B2)
‚Ä¢ Combined B1/B2 visas

It must be completed before scheduling the consular interview.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
Required documentation:

1. Valid passport (6+ months validity)
2. Recent digital photo (5x5 cm, white background)
3. Travel itinerary (flights, accommodation)
4. Proof of economic/social ties in your country
5. For B1: Company letter detailing trip purpose
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
1. Complete the DS-160 online:
   - Personal data
   - Travel history
   - Employment information
   - U.S. contacts

2. Pay the MRV fee ($160 USD)

3. Schedule interview at the consulate

4. Attend appointment with all documents
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
To increase approval chances:

‚Ä¢ Verify all data 3 times
‚Ä¢ Answers must match your documentation
‚Ä¢ Prepare for the interview:
  - Clearly explain trip purpose
  - Demonstrate you'll return to your country
  - Bring original documents and copies

‚Ä¢ Avoid mentioning intent to work or study
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: The DS-160 doesn't guarantee visa approval. The final decision is made by the consular officer during the interview. Typical processing: 2-3 weeks.

serviceItems.title: Family Sponsorship
serviceItems.description: Green Card for relatives with Form I-130.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Help your relative obtain lawful permanent residence in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-130 is used by U.S. citizens and permanent residents to:

‚Ä¢ Establish a qualifying relationship with a foreign relative
‚Ä¢ Initiate the family-based immigration process
‚Ä¢ Secure a visa number for eligible relatives

This is the first step in obtaining a Green Card for your family member.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
U.S. Citizens Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Parents
- Children (any age/marital status)
- Siblings

Permanent Residents Can Petition:
- Spouse
- Unmarried children (any age)

Note: You must file separate I-130 forms for each relative.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Essential evidence includes:

1. Proof of your status:
   - Birth certificate (U.S. citizens)
   - Naturalization certificate
   - Green Card (permanent residents)

2. Proof of relationship:
   - Marriage certificates
   - Birth certificates
   - Adoption decrees

3. Financial support evidence (for later I-864 filing)
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
1. File Form I-130 with USCIS
2. Wait for petition approval
3. Relative applies for visa:
   - Abroad: Through consular processing
   - In U.S.: Via Form I-485 adjustment

Processing Times:
‚Ä¢ Immediate relatives: No wait
‚Ä¢ Others: Varies by category/country (1-10+ years)

Note: All applicants must pass medical and background checks
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: Approval of I-130 doesn't guarantee a visa. Your relative must still meet all eligibility requirements. Consult an immigration attorney for complex cases.

serviceItems.title: DACA Renewal
serviceItems.description: Renew your DACA status with Form I-821D.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Temporary protection for eligible individuals who came to the U.S. as children
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
‚Ä¢ Renewals Only: USCIS currently only processes DACA renewal applications
‚Ä¢ No New Applications: Initial applications are not being accepted
‚Ä¢ Limited Window: Only recipients whose status expires between September 5, 2017 and March 5, 2018 can renew

Note: Those who never had DACA cannot currently apply
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify for DACA you must:

1. Have entered U.S. before age 16
2. Been under 31 as of June 15, 2012
3. Lived continuously in U.S. since June 15, 2007
4. Been physically present on June 15, 2012
5. Had no lawful status as of June 15, 2012
6. Meet education/military requirements:
   - Currently in school OR
   - High school diploma/GED OR
   - Honorably discharged veteran
7. No serious criminal history
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Proof needed includes:

‚Ä¢ Identity Documents:
  - Passport/birth certificate
  - Government-issued IDs

‚Ä¢ Continuous Residence Proof:
  - School/medical records
  - Employment history
  - Financial records

‚Ä¢ Education/Military Proof:
  - Diplomas/transcripts
  - GED certificate
  - Military service records
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
For eligible renewals:

1. File Form I-821D
2. Submit Form I-765 for work authorization
3. Pay $495 fee
4. Provide biometrics
5. Wait for USCIS processing

Processing Time: Typically 4-6 months

Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work authorization
‚Ä¢ Social Security number

Note: DACA does NOT provide:
‚Ä¢ Legal permanent status
‚Ä¢ Path to citizenship
‚Ä¢ Federal financial aid eligibility
serviceItems.contentFinal: Important: If your DACA expired after March 2018, consult an immigration attorney immediately. Court rulings may affect program availability - check USCIS website for updates before applying.

serviceItems.title: Asylum Application
serviceItems.description: Assistance with Form I-589 for asylum seekers.
serviceItems.content: Protection from Persecution in the U.S.
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: Legal process for individuals fearing persecution in their home country
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText:
Form I-589 serves three key purposes:

‚Ä¢ Application for asylum (permanent protection)
‚Ä¢ Request for withholding of removal (deportation protection)
‚Ä¢ Protection under the Convention Against Torture (CAT)

This is the primary form for seeking protection in the U.S. based on fear of persecution.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
To qualify you must:

1. Demonstrate well-founded fear of persecution due to:
   - Race/Religion
   - Nationality
   - Political opinion
   - Social group membership

2. Be physically present in the U.S. (regardless of entry method)
3. File within 1 year of arrival (with exceptions for extraordinary circumstances)
4. Not have:
   - Previous deportation orders
   - Denied asylum application after full hearing
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
Essential evidence includes:

‚Ä¢ Completed Form I-589
‚Ä¢ Detailed personal statement:
  - Specific incidents of persecution
  - Country conditions
  - Why you can't return

‚Ä¢ Supporting evidence:
  - Medical/psychological reports
  - Police reports
  - News articles
  - Witness statements
  - Certified translations of all foreign documents

‚Ä¢ Two passport-style photos
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
Filing Steps:
1. Complete and sign Form I-589
2. Compile supporting evidence
3. Submit to USCIS
4. Attend biometrics appointment
5. Interview with asylum officer
6. Receive decision

Potential Benefits:
‚Ä¢ Protection from deportation
‚Ä¢ Work authorization
‚Ä¢ Path to permanent residency
‚Ä¢ Ability to petition for family members
‚Ä¢ Access to social services
serviceItems.contentFinal:
Important: Asylum cases are complex. Strongly recommended to:
‚Ä¢ Consult with an immigration attorney
‚Ä¢ Submit application within 1-year deadline
‚Ä¢ Provide detailed, consistent evidence
‚Ä¢ Check USCIS website for current processing times

serviceItems.title: Certificate of Citizenship
serviceItems.description: Establish your status with Form N-600.
serviceItems.content: Certificate of U.S. Citizenship: Form N-600
serviceItems.contentSubtitle: A person born outside the United States to U.S. citizen parents may have already acquired U.S. citizenship. To document their citizenship status based on their ancestry, they can file Form N-600, Application for Certificate of Citizenship.
serviceItems.contentFirstPointText: A person can file Form N-600 if they are trying to claim U.S. citizenship by law while in the United States or if they were born abroad to U.S. citizen parents.
serviceItems.contentSecondPointText:
They automatically become a U.S. citizen if they meet the following requirements:
- Citizen Parent: At least one parent is a U.S. citizen by birth or through the naturalization process.
- Residence in the United States: The individual lives in the U.S. with their U.S. citizen parent.
- Legal Admission as a Permanent Resident: The individual was legally admitted as a permanent resident.
- Underage: The individual is still under 18 years of age.
- Legal Custody: The individual is the biological child under the legal custody of a U.S. citizen parent before turning 16.
serviceItems.contentThirdPointText:
An individual born outside the United States to U.S. citizen parents may claim citizenship automatically at birth if they meet the following requirements:
- Both parents are U.S. citizens, and one of them resided in the U.S. before the individual's birth.
- Or, if one parent is a foreign citizen and the other is a U.S. citizen who, before the individual's birth, was physically present in the U.S. for a period or periods totaling no less than five years, at least two of which were after the parent turned 14.
serviceItems.contentFourPointText:
A person may also apply for a Certificate of Citizenship if the following happened before turning 18 and before February 27, 2001:
- The individual lived continuously in the U.S. after being legally admitted as a permanent resident; and
- Both parents, the parent awarded physical and legal custody, or the sole surviving parent is a U.S. citizen by naturalization.
serviceItems.contentFivePoint: Application by a Parent or Guardian
serviceItems.contentFivePointText: If an individual was adopted or is the biological child under 18 who meets the requirements for citizenship under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Form N-600 application must be submitted by the U.S. citizen parent or legal guardian who has legal and physical custody of the child.
serviceItems.contentSixPointText: To start the process, you must complete and submit Form N-600 along with the required documentation demonstrating that you meet the specified criteria. This certificate serves as official proof of your status as a U.S. citizen.
